body:
For those familiar with the political compass, the triangle is a similar model, but instead of dividing economic vs social stances, it compares the 3 different main philosophies: equality (left), hierarchy (right), and individualism (libertarian). This resolves a few issues with the square compass, such as inconsistencies regarding the meanings of libertarian and right wing.

I made a small quiz to determine your position. It can be taken here: https://crystalvulpine.github.io/PoliticalTriangle/quiz.html

I'll go first. Here's where I am:

![](https://i.imgur.com/LoxdpZY.png)

100% pure based libertarian ancap

body:
There are 2 different left/right spectrums, and that is precisely the predicament that the triangle attempts to solve.

In the American version, left means socialism and big government, and right means individualism (libertarian). However, on the traditional axis, left means equality, while right favors hierarchy and legislation supporting such. There are 2 completely different right wings, and the triangle represents both.
body_html:
There are 2 different left/right spectrums, and that is precisely the predicament that the triangle attempts to solve.

In the American version, left means socialism and big government, and right means individualism (libertarian). However, on the traditional axis, left means equality, while right favors hierarchy and legislation supporting such. There are 2 completely different right wings, and the triangle represents both.

body:
Did you read the introduction?
This doesn't even have a "right wing" (in the traditional political sense).
The right side of the triangle favours hierarchy and the left side of the triangle favours equality.
I'm pretty sure Mussolini and Hitler favoured hierarchy over equality.
It's nothing to do with the usual left-right wings.

It's nothing to do with the usual left-right wings.

body:
![](https://i.imgur.com/yK8yytZ.png)

I like the concept. My only critique is that it feels as if the answers may be subtly, perhaps unintentionally, written to favor the libertarian corner. On several questions, my preferred answer was some combination or middle ground between the libertarian and right-wing options, at which point I typically chose the libertarian option because it was framed in a slightly more favorable way. I appreciated the increased number of options over the political compass format, though I think there is room for even more nuance yet. 

Or perhaps I'm more of a "leave me the fuck alone" libertarian than I realized. Either way, really cool creation OP.

body:
Yeah, I literally published it 2 hours ago so this is more of a prototype atm. Some questions have more options because they can have a more moderate vs extreme stance. However, I've gotten a lot of complaints already that the auth options are unattractive, which doesn't surprise me considering my own stance. I'll need feedback from those people on how to reword them to be closer to what the left & right sides actually believe in.

The problem with agree/disagree is that it forces you to take a stance on every issue, with no option to say it should be left up to individuals. It assumes a 2-dimensional spectrum instead of 3. But some people still don't agree with any of the available options. I just added a neutral option to help with that, hopefully it improves the accuracy of people's scores by not making them choose one of the 3 sides if they don't have an opinion on something.

body:
I was actually expecting the libertarian options to seem more favorable, because I lean *very* heavily that way myself. This is a well-known phenomenon on these tests and the most famous example is how politicalcompass.org puts almost everyone in the libleft quadrant. I'll have to talk to more actual right/left-wing people to understand what they actually feel they believe in, and update the answers accordingly. If anyone has any suggestions, please share them.

I tried to provide both extreme and moderate options on each answer, however that was hard to do for some of them, and as such some of the questions have only 3 answers. I added a neutral option so hopefully that improves things a bit. In any case, go with the answer that is closest to your own belief, as probably nothing will ever fit it perfectly.

parent.body:
![](https://i.imgur.com/yK8yytZ.png)

I like the concept. My only critique is that it feels as if the answers may be subtly, perhaps unintentionally, written to favor the libertarian corner. On several questions, my preferred answer was some combination or middle ground between the libertarian and right-wing options, at which point I typically chose the libertarian option because it was framed in a slightly more favorable way. I appreciated the increased number of options over the political compass format, though I think there is room for even more nuance yet. 

Or perhaps I'm more of a "leave me the fuck alone" libertarian than I realized. Either way, really cool creation OP.

post.body:
For those familiar with the political compass, the triangle is a similar model, but instead of dividing economic vs social stances, it compares the 3 different main philosophies: equality (left), hierarchy (right), and individualism (libertarian). This resolves a few issues with the square compass, such as inconsistencies regarding the meanings of libertarian and right wing.

I made a small quiz to determine your position. It can be taken here: https://crystalvulpine.github.io/PoliticalTriangle/quiz.html

I'll go first. Here's where I am:

![](https://i.imgur.com/LoxdpZY.png)

100% pure based libertarian ancap

body:
![](https://files.catbox.moe/qsdqk9.jpeg)

Pretty nice for a simple test. I think simplifying the pct into 3 sections makes more sense than 4. There probably needs to be some refining on the equatist and hierarchist sections, maybe making their answers a little less aggressive in some cases. I do also like how there was a focus away from specific policy positions since those muddy away the concept of general political alignment

Did you read the introduction?
This doesn't even have a "right wing" (in the traditional political sense).
The right side of the triangle favours hierarchy and the left side of the triangle favours equality.
I'm pretty sure Mussolini and Hitler favoured hierarchy over equality.
It's nothing to do with the usual left-right wings.

parent.body:
There are 2 different left/right spectrums, and that is precisely the predicament that the triangle attempts to solve.

In the American version, left means socialism and big government, and right means individualism (libertarian). However, on the traditional axis, left means equality, while right favors hierarchy and legislation supporting such. There are 2 completely different right wings, and the triangle represents both.

For those familiar with the political compass, the triangle is a similar model, but instead of dividing economic vs social stances, it compares the 3 different main philosophies: equality (left), hierarchy (right), and individualism (libertarian). This resolves a few issues with the square compass, such as inconsistencies regarding the meanings of libertarian and right wing.

I made a small quiz to determine your position. It can be taken here: https://crystalvulpine.github.io/PoliticalTriangle/quiz.html

I'll go first. Here's where I am:

![](https://i.imgur.com/LoxdpZY.png)

100% pure based libertarian ancap

body:
Libertarians don't believe the government should be involved in social issues, something the square compass can't represent as it only has a conservative/progressive axis.

The triangle test is more about your attitudes towards the 3 main political values, rather than asserting your beliefs in specific areas. However, it is probably a good indicator of those.

Also, you can't really be both left (equality & community) and individualist at the same time, they require a trade-off. You can however, be in between, which is where I'd place left libertarians. The square doesn't do a great job at illustrating this, or any individualist opinions at all for that matter.

body:
What does auth right mean to you? And what about the two sides makes you say that?

(I'm only asking this because I'm trying to get a better understanding of what the left and right ideologies identify with so it can be tested much better. So far all the other political tests haven't done that, leaving it skewed immensely towards the views of the test creator (the same way mine is towards the libertarian side atm, for example politicalcompass.org has an extreme libleft bias). I want this to finally be a version that isn't like that).

body:
Well, I would consider myself a religious Catholic. I believe many (but not all) social views fall in auth right. (It’d be wrong to define the Catholic Church totally a certain section of a compass) That’s why I’d consider myself auth-right. I usually associate traditional Christian values mostly with auth right.

I believe abortion is wrong. I believe everyone was created equal in the eyes of God. Therefore I believe in equality of **opportunity**, and that the US had that, and those protesting rn are literally trying to fight against that.  Equality of outcome is unfair. Your outcome should be dependent on how much you try. Those who don’t try to better themselves should get nothing. 

Economically I believe that there capitalism is good, but there has to be some restrictions. I’ve been educated in both for and against monopolies. Personally I believe that there has to be some limit on monopolies. If left unlimited, there will be no competition, and new businesses would not be able to open. I believe that the majority of the wealth would end up in the hands of a few. Most people would be paid poorly. I don’t remember learning about any time in history when unlimited capitalism wasn’t like this. (Feel free to prove me wrong or disagree). This doesn’t mean that I’d want a planned economy like far leftists do.

The only thing that would put me over the lib line IMO, is that I’m not trying to force my opinions on everyone. I’d love for everyone to share my opinions, but people shouldn’t be forced to believe the way I do. I do think that there does have to be a basic sense of morality in society, (and Christian morality has proven effective). 


Also, my results on your Political triangle test actually seem to be consistent with the political compass test.

Is this nonsense? I’m 17, so I may not know what I’m talking about, and I’m also kinda tired.

body: The test only assesses your attitude towards government, all other personal beliefs are completely irrelevant. As you stated that you don't want your opinions forced on people, that's libertarian. You also don't sound like someone on the (traditional, not American) right to me: their system is built on hierarchy, with the most extreme form being caste-like systems; they specifically *don't* believe that everyone is created equal. You sound more like someone in the middle, which matches up with your test results (remember, right and left here are the old-school axis of legislated hierarchy vs equality, the American right-wing is the libertarian section on the triangle).

parent.body:
Well, I would consider myself a religious Catholic. I believe many (but not all) social views fall in auth right. (It’d be wrong to define the Catholic Church totally a certain section of a compass) That’s why I’d consider myself auth-right. I usually associate traditional Christian values mostly with auth right.

I believe abortion is wrong. I believe everyone was created equal in the eyes of God. Therefore I believe in equality of **opportunity**, and that the US had that, and those protesting rn are literally trying to fight against that.  Equality of outcome is unfair. Your outcome should be dependent on how much you try. Those who don’t try to better themselves should get nothing. 

Economically I believe that there capitalism is good, but there has to be some restrictions. I’ve been educated in both for and against monopolies. Personally I believe that there has to be some limit on monopolies. If left unlimited, there will be no competition, and new businesses would not be able to open. I believe that the majority of the wealth would end up in the hands of a few. Most people would be paid poorly. I don’t remember learning about any time in history when unlimited capitalism wasn’t like this. (Feel free to prove me wrong or disagree). This doesn’t mean that I’d want a planned economy like far leftists do.

The only thing that would put me over the lib line IMO, is that I’m not trying to force my opinions on everyone. I’d love for everyone to share my opinions, but people shouldn’t be forced to believe the way I do. I do think that there does have to be a basic sense of morality in society, (and Christian morality has proven effective). 


Also, my results on your Political triangle test actually seem to be consistent with the political compass test.

Is this nonsense? I’m 17, so I may not know what I’m talking about, and I’m also kinda tired.
